abstract: So how much does JPMorgan Chase stand to lose from the upheaval in the auto industry, with General Motors becoming the latest company to file for bankruptcy? That’s hard to say, TheStreet.com reports.
snippet: So how much does JPMorgan Chase stand to lose from the upheaval in the auto industry, with General Motors becoming the latest company to file for bankruptcy? That’s hard to say, TheStreet.com reports.
lead_paragraph: So how much does JPMorgan Chase stand to lose from the upheaval in the auto industry, with General Motors becoming the latest company to file for bankruptcy? That’s hard to say, TheStreet.com reports.

headline.main: Taking a Look at JPMorgan’s Auto Exposure

abstract: The Federal Reserve plans to announce next week an “initial set” of banks that can repay government support, and escape the restrictions that came with it.
snippet: The Federal Reserve plans to announce next week an “initial set” of banks that can repay government support, and escape the restrictions that came with it.
lead_paragraph: Since the government pressed billions of dollars in taxpayer support on the nation’s banks, several strong institutions have been pushing to give it back. Now a few of them may get the go-ahead next week  a crucial step in disentangling themselves from Washington.

headline.main: Banks May Soon Get Approval to Leave the Bailout Program
headline.print_headline: Banks May Soon Get Approval To Leave the Bailout Program

abstract: The Federal Reserve laid out rules on Monday for banks seeking to repay taxpayer bailout funds, as two financial companies — JPMorgan Chase and American Express — said that they planned to tap the equity markets to do just that.
snippet: The Federal Reserve laid out rules on Monday for banks seeking to repay taxpayer bailout funds, as two financial companies — JPMorgan Chase and American Express — said that they planned to tap the equity markets to do just that.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve laid out rules on Monday for banks seeking to repay taxpayer bailout funds, as two financial companies — JPMorgan Chase and American Express — said that they planned to tap the equity markets to do just that.

headline.main: Fed Sets Rules for Banks to Repay Bailout Money
